> Could you elaborate a bit on "entering a thought" though? That struck me as interesting earlier as well while reading through the chat. Did it start after the click, and is it the same feeling as experiencing self-image/belief pre-SR?

I noticed it before SR too, yes.

In sleep paralysis, I figured out how to lucid dream, and it was by imagining a scenario, and then trying to "move towards it", and then this would slowly make you "enter into that thought", creating a lucid dream around that scenario.

I would also notice myself falling asleep, like right on the cusp of it, and I would notice that I would have an initial thought, and then slowly the thought would get more and more immersive, and I would jump out of it for a second and be like "Oh I was just immersed in that thought I was having." I really think anyone can notice it if they go to sleep and think about things incessantly on the bed, like think about some future scenario or something you're passionate about, you will get sucked into it slowly.

It didn't start after the click, anyone can notice it if they try.

As for if it is the same feeling as prior to SR, yes, but my dream self never experiences anxiety or anything, my dream self is also self-realized basically. There's no nightmares or feelings of "doom" as you might find in certain dreams. 

I also think that when you do start dreaming, it is like a very intense imagination/hallucination completely created by mind, which cannot be found in the waking state or the cusp before sleeping. It reaches a very vivid intensity. You can even feel pain in your dreams but it is very dull when it happens.

> This is a very fascinating idea too. 

I really do look at thoughts/daydreams/self-image as mild forms of "dreaming" because I truly believe it is made out of the same "stuff" and it just gets amplified at night. It just might not feel like a dream because you're awake at the same time and so you have the experience of being awake to contrast it and pull you out of it. I definitely 100% perceive myself "entering a thought" when I am going into a dream or on the few occasions that I have entered a lucid dream.

I also theorize this is why you cannot have an internal monologue while dreaming as well, all the voices in a dream are external and spoken out loud. An inner monologue exists within the same medium that the dream exists within, which is your imagination. Inner monologues happen inside your head, and the dream state exists inside your head, so to speak. In order to perceive an "inner monologue" the waking state must be there to contrast it, which is not the case when you are dreaming.

I think there is like a really simple way to shift how you look at things but people get bogged up in the context too much. If there is context around your experience it doesn't matter because it is around the experience. All that matters is experience, not the science or explanation behind it or how much understanding you have of it. It doesn't matter how good your understanding of red is, that is still not red. It doesn't matter how good your understanding of vanilla is, that is still not the taste of vanilla. You examine what your experience of red is, you don't examine the reasoning behind it. You examine what your experience of vanilla is, you don't examine the reasoning behind it. This is what it means to use intellect on your senses. Most people use intellect on intellect, which simply means they are using "thoughts on thoughts" and simply creating more knowledge about their experience instead of examining experience.

When you're playing Minecraft, you don't experience the code that runs it, you experience Minecraft. It's that direct and simple. Examine that experience, don't examine code from that experience, that is silliness.

Yeah psychedelic experiences are very powerful. Humans imagine all sorts of crazy things from the sober state, imagine what a psychedelic state would do. The potential for delusion there is definitely massive and it can become a big red herring. Every single person I've seen who uses psychedelics as a crutch for "chasing higher and truer states" is basically in like some kind of borderline psychosis, in that they will have very weird metaphysical/pseudo-spiritual views that they bring back.
a kundalini experience could then be considered kensho, or a psychedelic experience
there are lots of "breadcrumbs" or powerful experiences that come before "it" which can give insights

As for combining it with self-inquiry, I've seen people do that and the same thing I described above happened, they would spin stories about all the different crazy states and insights that they gathered from it. But it could be helpful in that it might bring some kind of understanding back to the sober state which you can then use for inquiry, that is possible. But I really believe it has to be done sober ultimately. A chemical is not gonna do it simply because it wears off. 

What I'm talking about is basically what is called "Makyo" in Zen, which refers to strange or supernatural experiences you might encounter on the path, all of which are distractions which the mind easily latches on to. Psychedelics are basically an instantaneous way of creating Makyo and they can potentially become a distraction, that is all my point is.

It's not a coincidence that "it" happened sober every single recorded time in history.

Psychedelics are not gonna carry any kind of click back to your sober state because they wear off in the same way that alcohol makes you feel good but it always wears off, it has a biochemical limit. The psychedelics essentially put a temporary biochemical limiter on your ability to form self-image, in the same way that alcohol limits your ability to think about things temporarily. Enlightenment is having full functionality of all of those capabilities and simultaneously not being sucked into self-image, that is what it means to be enlightened, it is keeping that realization while having the capabilities of the sober state. 

For example, if you took some substance which prevents you from thinking about past or future, it will create a kind of "pseudo-enlightenment" because you literally cannot access past or future anymore. You are not capable or intelligent enough to even create a self-image, because that ability is either removed or inhibited by the substance. And of course the chemical allowing that will wear off eventually. 

They might be good for opening your mind if you have a very fixed mindset about reality. Knowledge-based belief concludes about what is not directly experienced. Self-image based belief makes a conclusion about what you are directly experiencing. The self-image based belief is mistaking knowledge for experience, which creates a belief about direct experience, and that belief about direct experience is equivalent to identity/self-image.

It is possible to have incorrect knowledge, or to know something that is incorrect, without having self-image. There are beliefs strictly based on gathering knowledge which I will try to exemplify.

> I KNOW that this hair product has ingredients 

For example, I wouldn't consider this belief to be self-image. This is the type of belief I am talking about. Knowing is knowledge, you can spawn all sorts of self-beliefs from this particular belief, but the clinging to knowledge is nothing to do with a self, however, that knowledge can substantiate a belief.

It is a fact that you know that the hair product has the ingredients that you want, but it is not a fact that you are actually experiencing those ingredients. Knowing something is not the same as experiencing it. Your knowing here is based on past experience, the brand name, ingredient label, or whatever else. You are not genuinely experiencing that the ingredient is actually present and you are aware of this, but you are extrapolating through other perceptions and using Occams Razor.

On the other hand, a self-image based belief makes a claim about experience, in other words, it makes a claim about you. That is the distinction. Self-belief is saying I am experiencing myself as this. Knowledge-based belief is saying I am experiencing these things, which leads me to believe that this product contains this ingredient. The knowledge-based belief offshoots itself to something that is not directly experienced.

Self-image belief goes like this:

>This bad event happened to me 
>I am always experiencing me 
>I am hopeless

Knowledge-based belief goes like this:

>I experience an event 
>I learn data from that event 
>I form a conclusion about what is not directly experienced based on that data I experienced

Experientially, the line is really entirely vertical, as Osho said. The perception of a horizontal time frame is more knowing of time and more knowledge.

So from the present, you can only know that something happened in time, but you cannot experience time. Experiencing time is not the same as knowing time, in the same way that knowing about the color red is not the same as looking at the color red. The present gives you knowledge on past and future, not the past and future itself, just knowledge about it. 

Present experience being labeled "unknown" is accurate because you do not need to know something that is experienced, knowledge is a symbol/placeholder to extrapolate towards something you cannot know through experience. What is known is that which is not presently experienced, which includes past, future, and any ideas about your experience itself. As example, there is no need to refer to a memory of yourself seeing the color red if the color red is present in the moment visually. As another example, you can have theories about how the computer in front of you is operating, but there is no need to theorize or know about what the computer itself is displaying since you are already experiencing that.

It makes perfect sense why the present experience would be "unknowable", because "knowing" happens as an activity inside of that experience. The present experience transcends "knowing" and acts as a foreground for "knowing" to occur. You don't always know everything, it is also possible to not know something, therefore knowing is not inherent to experience. When I say "knowing" I am talking about knowledge.

Beliefs about yourself are "wrong" in that they are not ever actually related to your experience of yourself. Beliefs about anything else are not "wrong" because you can actually observe them as beliefs, and so you are well aware it is simply knowledge you have gathered and that you are acting on it in your best interest.

If you believe that you have your car keys and you realize that you left it in the house by accident, there is nothing emotionally related to yourself that occurs because in that moment you are accurately perceiving the belief as a belief. When it comes to a belief about yourself, or "self-belief", it is never actually seen as a belief but rather as a core feature of yourself, and thus it is always a false perception. When you believe you have your car keys, you are well aware it is a belief being held by you. When you have a belief about yourself, you are not aware of this, you don't think the belief is being held by you, but rather you think the belief itself is you.

If all beliefs are false, or potentially false, what can you know to be 100% true? What is there that cannot be questioned or believed in?

What if you are wrong? What does it mean to be wrong? If you have no beliefs about anything, is it still possible to be wrong?

Learning and planning happens now.

Past and future is also perceived from what is happening right now.

You don't perceive the past from the past or the future from the future. You perceive both through the present moment.

How can the past and future occur simultaneously, if it is truly a genuine occurrence? Past and future are opposite to eachother. 

Your thoughts are a way to bridge your inability to experience past or future, but the thoughts are not past and future, thoughts are like a middleman which roughly translates the past and future. Imagining time is not the same as experiencing it.

> do you literally not know who you are?

Self-realization is like figuring out what you aren't. The problem is when you think you are something that you aren't. What you gain from self-realization is a subtraction or removal of false ideas about yourself.

It's like playing Super Mario thinking you are Bowser, it would be confusing to play in that way. And then one day realizing you were actually Mario imagining that it is Bowser the entire time, and now that you know you are Mario you can finally play the game properly.

You can't "know" who you are because you are the canvas in which knowing and thinking occurs. It creates a recursion error. You can't know experience, you can only experience experience, and experience itself includes knowing.

> Maybe you don't even think you are human anymore?

Why do I have to think I am a human if I am in fact a human? Thinking is an activity that humans engage in. If I stop thinking, will I stop being human? 

> How does it feel to describe yourself to another person? Is it futile?

It's not futile because the other person is not me and they cannot view my experience, so that is the only way to convey myself to them.

> Why does it freak you out if you don't know who you are?

Gonna assume you meant to say "doesn't"?

Nothing in experience really changes aside from belief. It's not like the laws of physics start changing or something. So what is there to be freaked out about? Same old.

> Isn't it important to know?

In general, yes, but trying to know yourself is like trying to measure temperature with a ruler. It is equally important to know that rulers can't measure temperature.

> How do you assure yourself that you exist without a sense of self, and without knowing what you are?

Are you asking, how am I sure?

Do you have to assure yourself when hearing sound or seeing color? It is experiential, not knowledge-based, so that is where the certainty comes from.

I wasn't trying to say that awareness is detached from your body or that things are not physical.

What kind of experience is your eye and body and all your organs actually creating, if you believe it is being created that way? The creation process is irrelevant, what is the end result? Forget whether it is physical or ethereal or whatever, that does not matter. What is your experience of it? What kind of experience is your body actually creating? That's the focus.

Your experience of the world is not just your body either, it includes many other things, so why base your identity on that separation? 

It's not "your experience of body", it's more like "your experience of the world, which includes a body."

Thinking you are a human is different from being a human. One is thinking, one is being/experiencing. The latter even includes thinking as an activity which occurs inside it.

"Both body and experience" is a false dichotomy because a body is experienced, there is no "both", it is one thing. Experience includes body.

If your body was pulverized your entire surrounding would "vanish", if we go with the hypothetical.

Then, why do you separate body? Have you ever experienced your body just by itself?

You can imagine some creation process regarding a body or controller or whatever, but what are you actually experiencing? What is the end result of that process? What is that experience?

When you play Minecraft there is code running in the background, but you aren't experiencing code, you are experiencing Minecraft. The code is a creation process, Minecraft is the end result of that.

Also, what is your experience of "things being separate from your awareness"? We are focusing first and foremost on your experience of yourself. Can you find something in experience that is separate from your awareness of it? What does it actually mean to be aware of something separate from awareness, is that actually experientially possible, or is it something you must extrapolate through thought and belief?

I think Jamie's quote which was aforementioned by Tyler and also this one are both trying to touch on a difference of content and structure. What needs to be focused on is the structure of thoughts/experience, not the content.

In the same way that you can look at a keyboard through vision, but you wouldn't say "vision is a keyboard", the activity/ability of vision is a "container" to view the keyboard so to speak. It is a sense perception first and foremost, and that sense perception "contains" various things inside it, but the mechanism of that sense perception does not change despite what is contained inside it.

The "clouds passing through a sky" analogy is basically trying to get yourself to see yourself as the sky/container for the content/clouds, instead of getting lost in the clouds/content of experience. "Clouds" are duality, "sky" is oneness/non-duality.

Instead of questioning the content, you question how you are viewing the content in the first place. The former is looking at the content, the latter is looking at the structure.

The belief goes like this:

>I think about myself (past or future)

>This causes a belief in the present moment that you carry over from the past or future. "I am stupid, I am doomed, etc."

>Since you imagine yourself, you naturally emotionally react to that belief you created. If you believe you are stupid, a reaction is created to try and fix that. If you believe your life is doomed, a reaction is created to try and fix that. In the exact same way you would emotionally and physiologically react to a bear, you take the same precaution to your imagination about the past and future simply because you believe that you can imagine yourself.

The superficial link that the self-image uses to impose itself is belief. The belief can be created in the present moment. However, the past and future cannot be recreated in the present moment. The belief is based on the past and future, and it takes advantage of that to create self-image in the present.

I talked about this a bit in my realizationinquiry.txt so I'll just paste it here:

> So whats happening when you identify with thought is:
> 
> >> pure sense perception (thought)
> 
> >> the real you decides to act as if the thought is true (anxiety, heart racing, avoidant behaviour, self-deprecation (more thoughts), etc)
> 
> Unknowingly, you are extrapolating thought into something that is not thought (physical symptoms mentioned before), which experientially makes it SEEM like thought is connected to experience, but it absolutely isn't.
> 
> There's no objects in thought.
> 
> The connection with thought is a self-fulfilling prophecy. You get spooked by a real event (physical symptoms), you create a belief about the experience that spooked you, and then this belief recreates REAL physical symptoms which cause you to misinterpret the thought as real.
> 
> If you recognize this unnecessary connection, the "realness", which is simply just physical symptoms, will stop. 

To expand on this a bit, the thought or memory is triggering or confirming a belief about yourself. You can't relive the experience, but you can relive the belief by creating it in the present moment, which causes you to also relive the symptoms.

This is exactly why you can be sitting on your bed, remember some cringey thing you did a few years ago, and then completely relive that situation emotionally while being on your bed. You didn't enter a social situation, you remembered a social situation you had from a long time ago, and that memory triggered the exact same belief that occurred at that time, which then triggered the same emotional and physiological reaction as well.

It is being curious about how your experience of yourself operates. A big part of that is questioning why you emotionally react to thoughts about yourself. There is an element in your experience called "self-image" which you need to question to realize how it operates.

Kundalini seems to be something that actually happens, and there are certain "energetic practices" which may or may not work. 

To clarify, I think people find certain experiences that they invoke within themselves which absolutely can be explained by science or biology or whatever, but it is simply not studied yet, and so certain cultures like Hinduism get a hold of it and explain it in their own way and terminology, some of which being kundalini.

I personally see kundalini as something similar to invoking a certain state, like you would do through psychedelics or meditation. It creates a very powerful experience which perhaps gives a sense of oneness or some such euphoria, but then it wears off after a while. People experience this and then start chasing after those experiences because of how blissful and "truthful" it felt. They realized that they felt "one" with the universe, and then they think, "Oh my god that enlightened guy said we're all one too, does that mean he is permanently in that kundalini state?" And then that potentially becomes a red herring.

I've always been interested in this stuff, so for me it felt like a hobby I could do forever and I basically enjoyed all of it, kind of like solving a murder mystery.

It was kind of like looking for a bug or glitch in a video game, If I look at my thoughts for long enough I might find a bug which lets me "break out of it."
Yeah for sure, all the context you need is in your present experience

Something like that. If someone tells you to shoot a target, that is an idea which captures exactly what must be done, but it is still an abstract idea, and that level of vagueness is good. The target could be anything and it could look like anything because it was not specified, but your mind is still able to scan your experience for "it."

For me personally, the idea that it could be a permanent shift was a massive revelation and motivator for me. Despite studying spirituality and enlightenment for so long, I never realized that was a possibility at all, and it really simplified and streamlined what I was looking for.  If your mind is already bogged up with so many ideas about spirituality or enlightenment, maybe it is not so bad to get another idea about it like "stop looking over there, it's actually right here." 

But aside from that, I also think it is important to define what we are looking for in a certain way, because many people simply start mistaking certain experiences for "it" and then start creating their own philosophies and worldviews out of it which completely branch into something else. That objectivity removes vagueness, and so it prevents you from replacing it with some other idea of it. But then of course, this can be dangerous, because you shouldn't obsess over a certain description or pointer too much, since it is not the thing itself. You would have to balance that out in your communication.

Certain ideas can be seen as better "pointers", although they are in fact all ideas. For example, no one in history has probably come up with the identity "I am Spongebob", for a good reason, which is that there is at least some sense that "my identity is related to what I'm experiencing right now." 

You then often see people really getting caught up in the limits of language and identity, and they will move on to these types of answers which are infallible and then cling onto them very hard. They will say something like, "I am consciousness" or "I am my entire experience", but those are still ideas. Ideas which point to the entirety of experience, and in that way they are "closer", but still ideas nonetheless. At that point, the identities become very tautological and basically meaningless as a result, because it just becomes an endless semantic game where they keep saying stuff like "I am everything" or "I am love" or "Everything is x, y, and z." They keep finding different words to point to consciousness or experience, basically.

Great article, I just read it and completely agree. I have personally seen the damage that giving out incessant answers can have, I have been in such spiritual circles, and basically what happens is that people start building knowledge about the "correct answers" to spiritual questions rather than experiencing it themselves, which creates a sort of "spiritual ego." No one in the group is enlightened, but they all have the answers to the universe, somehow.

Most legit teachers are naturally careful about this, because they are naturally tuned to how dubious the mind can be on grasping and borrowing answers. You will see that their teachings don't give answers, but all their communications are like fingers which point to your direct experience. That's why a lot of times it might seem like they are "jumping around" the thing they are trying to describe, they don't want to give you the answer, they want you to look for it yourself. Their words are tools for your own inquiry.

I think the personal terminology actually comes quite naturally, because once you personally reach it and start explaining it to other people it is not something you memorized, it is basically just you looking at your experience and describing it. So you are using all your unique vocabulary and knowledge you had before, but it is used as a conduit for your experience. You can see that JK, Osho, etc. all talk quite differently.

The development of the verbal understanding also happens naturally once you start talking to the people around you realize that they don't understand you at all, haha.

It is helpful to look at other people's metaphors and stuff and borrow it here and there though, but it is not helpful to have 10 people who teach through the exact same lingo, it is better to have 10 people who teach it differently, because I am sure that different types of teachings probably work better for different people.

My personal recommendation is to listen to Jamie's contemplations while directly examining your experience to aid your self-enquiry. I feel like this helped a lot for me personally. Even though you may have listened to it many times before, there is just so much insight packed into there that you will probably learn something new from it everytime you listen to it. You'll notice something you didn't grasp before. All 3 of them are useful.

Aside from that, I think it is helpful to confront this feeling that there is something "beyond" your experience that you are not aware of. Jamie had a really good analogy about someone tasting ice cream and then interpreting that as something beyond what it is, like "Is this taste correct? Am I committing a sin by tasting this? What if this ice cream doesn't actually taste good?"

Any beliefs you have about reality in general can be recognized as simply a function of human intellect. If you have questions that feel really real and fundamental to you like "What is God? What is reality? What is a sin? What is experience?", just ask yourself, how is it possible that someone can NOT have these beliefs and questions? If these ideas are so fundamental, how come certain animals like insects literally never encounter them in their life? The answer is because these questions and ideas are purely a perceptual function of human biology, the same as taste, colors, etc. And so when you interpret the flavour of ice cream through thought, you are not actually interpreting anything, there are just two sense perceptions: taste and thought. Both are generated by human biology and they can stop being generated later on.

Not that the questions/ideas have no validity. They are as real as the rest of your experience, but they ARE just questions/ideas ABOUT experience. So asking those is not changing experience. You are already experiencing what is 100% the case, whether you have questions about it or not.

The reason why the reduction of desire is related to self-image is because when you desire something, you are desiring something that doesn't exist in your experience, and anything that exists in your experience is literally you, so yes this would have an effect on how you react to desires.

So, you don't lose ambition or desire per say, but all that you desire is just exactly what is occurring right now, because that is the only thing you CAN desire. The thought "I want this", and then the actions that come after that are all you desire, because that is literally the only thing that exists in your experience. There is a very visceral realization that you can't desire something that doesn't exist in your experience, it's just impossible. It is seen that the desire for something is something you just completely willingly came up with, and the pursuing of that is something you are also willingly creating, and the feeling of desiring and creating is all that is desired and can be desired.

Existentially, you can't desire any THING, because to desire something it must not exist in your experience first. So, literally, by definition, all desires are about something that does not exist in your experience. So then, how are you desiring something that doesn't exist? Thought! If something is in your experience right now, you cannot desire it, so it becomes a catch-22. Everything that can be sought exists now. The only thing to be sought is purely just the action of seeking something, which is of course redundant to seek. The very action of seeking is all that you want, and so in a sense, there is nothing to seek aside from your attempt to seek something, and then this is where the idea of "the enlightened person has no desires" comes from.

This is not to say that desire is bad or redundant, but desire itself is recontextualized into something like a pleasant thought form that you are deciding to create. It's like daydreaming, or thinking of a cute animal, or thinking about a really beautiful picture you saw the other day. It can become unpleasant (current you reacts avoidantly) when you mix it with a belief that you are located inside that desire.

Self-image is still used. But YOU don't react to it. You only react to whatever is currently happening, and this also includes thoughts about things that are not happening, but they are ALWAYS explicitly perceived as thoughts.

If you have a thought "I need water", you react normally as someone who doesn't have water would, so you would get up and drink a glass of water. But, there is never a reaction to a "lack of water", because there is no such thing in experience. Only self-image can create the experience of a lack of water, for example, you imagine a version of yourself that has water and is hydrated, and then that creates a feeling of "lack" and "resistance" in the present moment. The "lack" appears in contrast to the self-image which doesn't lack. 

For a self-realized person there is EXISTENTIALLY no such thing as lack of water, this is recontextualized as simply just the physical sensation of thirst or dehydration, and then an action to accommodate for that. You experientially cannot perceive a "lack" of something, truly. Lack is always inferred. This might seem like a really silly distinction to make, but it is existentially just the case, and it ties into the "removal" of self from all other thoughts. When you perceive "lack", you are always consulting imagination/memory, which isn't you. This actually leads into a very important point, which is that imagination and memory should not be demonized, it is a very important tool for perceiving certain things, but it just can't perceive you.

I want to reiterate I'm not saying that I don't need water or something like that, functionally I would react the exact same. I just want to stress that your experience is incapable of truly perceiving "lack." "Lack of water" is not something that I AM, I am literally just the sensation of dehydration and then a thought saying "I should get water", and then this bundle of experience could be inferred as a "lack of water", but that inference is not experienced at all.

> Also, how do things like non-duality play a part in all this?

You don't really have to worry about this and it might stimulate your logical side too much, but it's kind of how when you look at a painting of the Mona Lisa, the painting is one thing, it is just one painting ultimately, but it contains a person (Mona Lisa), and a background, and scenery, etc. all contained inside it. 

Just like the painting, you have one experience of yourself which contains other things inside it.

Non-duality becomes realized, because anything you try to point to as a single part of your experience, it immediately becomes "not you", and just an abstraction of you/experience. In the same way that you wouldn't consider a drawing of Mona Lisa by herself to be the Mona Lisa, and you wouldn't consider just the background of the Mona Lisa to be the Mona Lisa.

Just as an exercise, you can look at objects/experience around you and ask: "Is this laptop searching for itself?" "Is this table searching for itself?" "Is my chair searching for itself?" "Is my visual perception searching for itself?" "Is my experience searching for itself?" "Am I searching for myself?"

Your existence is truly equally as seamless as any object or aspect of your experience right now. And you are simply just what the experience is as a whole.

Somewhat paradoxically, the thing being searched for is found when the desire for the search ends. The lack of searching for something gives you what you are searching for. "Searching" in this case simply exists as a mental phenomenon which says "I need to find something that isn't being experienced right now."

Furthermore, maybe to put it another way, the searching of something is a self-fulfilling prophecy, and creates emptiness, because it immediately creates a condition saying "Something needs to be searched for which is not experienced right now and exists elsewhere."

Here's a perspective:

It's not that you don't exist, but rather, the real you which does exist is acting to compensate for something it doesn't have to compensate for. You're creating a partitioned identity through thoughts, and then the real you is linking that to its experience of itself by creating a real reaction to it through physical symptoms and avoidant behavior. This link is superficial, and it can be severed, which is what leads to self-realization. And this link is also why your negative emotions might linger on even after an event has concluded. You continually perpetuate the initial emotions caused by the event by imagining this partitioned identity which is still affected by the incident, despite the incident not even existing in your experience anymore. You're living two lives: The one which is not experiencing the event, and the one that is still experiencing the event. This discrepancy has to be investigated. In a certain sense you could say that self-realization is just experiencing one event all the time, which is yourself, whereas the average person feels like their identity is afflicted by multiple events constantly.

To emphasize this "superficial link", it's like reading a book about yourself, and then in the book it describes you as a "dumbass" or a "murderer", and then the real you reads that and reacts: "Oh my god, I'm not any of those things! What am I gonna do about this!", but there is literally nothing to do because you're just reading words about yourself, and they are just words, so there is no action to take in response to words. The words don't lower your intelligence or turn you into a murderer, so there is no necessary input from you.

The words inside of the book here is analogous to self-image and the thoughts you have about yourself.

Well, you can think about yourself. But it's always ABOUT yourself. So the thought itself is a mere simulation/abstraction of something that exists outside that thought form. It's always ABOUT something, not the thing itself.

Really, all thoughts are equally as real as any other. The thought of a unicorn is equally as real as a thought of yourself. They're both thoughts. In the same way that all books are equally books. Some books might have better descriptions of reality, but they are all books, and they cannot break the limitations of being books. Same goes for thoughts. You can write a detailed biography about yourself, but it never amounts to anything other than a book. It's just stuck in that medium. It's not gonna eventually turn into a real version of you at some point, because it's just a book.

In a similar way, no matter how accurately you think of yourself, it will never become accurate enough to transform into something real. The real you, which is outside of thought, has to actually do something to move beyond the limitations of thought.

The Mario analogy was also really good for this, so i'll just paste it again here:

You are still trying to point to something in the experience that is you, but you are the experience.

The entire experience cannot point to itself, because the pointer is not the entire experience, it is a subset of the experience, so this "pointing towards what I am" is an inefficient method/medium/tool for identifying yourself.

Because I feel it is relevant, I will share my own synopsis about what Jamie said with the Mario analogy in his "Self-Realization" video.

Your fundamental identity is what you are experiencing.

So, it's not that you are a human being, but rather, you are what the human being experiences.

Notice that, when you play Mario, even though you are controlling Mario, you are still experiencing the entire game, including Bowser, the goombas, Princess Peach, etc. These are all included inside of the experience of Mario. 

The game isn't JUST a guy named Mario, in the same way that your life isn't JUST a human being. Your life includes other human beings, it involves food, it involves music, etc. So, it's the entire experience of being a human, rather than just this secluded idea of "I am a human."

And, no word, thought, idea, or communication, will ever capture the experience, because, as stated before, these mediums are a subset of experience, therefore they cannot effectively point to experience.

As Jamie said, there are smarter and more holistic answers, like "I am consciousness" or "I am my entire experience", but these are JUST answers. Answers are not you. You do not exist as an answer. Answers are knowledge. Answers are just a limited sense perception, which is a subset of experience. So, it is still a trap to get stuck to answers. The medium is just wrong.

Once you've confirmed that nothing physical or genuinely threatening is happening, then it's just some person who is mentally distressed really. There's no "you" left over that has to defend itself, if that makes sense.

So, you have to turn the future into a fact first, in order to actually perceive it and be scared of it. You do this through the medium of thought. But, it's never actually the future, it's just a thought. And so there is no future or unseen future to be scared of, because you are stuck having to perceive it through the present moment through thought. It's just all in front of you, always. There is no "future" that is going to pop out of nowhere. That just becomes your present experience. So the previous thoughts you had about it are never it. And same goes for your current thoughts.

I actually detailed how it happened in the message I'm currently replying to, it just got buried further up in the chat I guess. @jamie0773 

But really, it was just this recognition that my entire experience is just a fact, and that any time I tried to interpret experience in a way that wasn't fact, it was through something that I was experiencing and directly aware of (thought), so all of it was ultimately something I had direct access to, which makes all of it a fact. I think a lot of the stress/anxiety that comes from thoughts is this feeling inside of us that we are constantly perceiving or predicting something that is hiding behind our experience, but no, the only way to interpret or hypothesize experience is to create an abstraction of experience through thought, that's it. And thoughts are always factually thought. So existentially, there's just no interpretation at all. And this "turned off" the part of my brain that was constantly imagining that I'm gonna be "attacked" by something that doesn't exist, because it just realized that I'm directly aware of everything I need to be aware of at all times.

Just think of it like this:

All these insights and contemplations are just trying to point you towards something that is in your experience RIGHT NOW. Your goal is not to integrate some philosophy or insight, but to spot this "thing" which is "hiding" somewhere in your experience. It's very direct. And if you stare at your experience long enough, you might notice it at some point, and then that is self-realization.

So, when someone says, "what are you", don't come up with an answer, actually try to spot "yourself" in your experience, and then maybe try to communicate any answers or observations you notice afterwards

Just look at your experience and question it, then the questions will unravel any assumptions you have about your experience. Your experience can't hide anything from you, so question it all you want. It's all there in front of you.

You might get questions sometimes that lead you the wrong way, so you have to question a lot of the questions themselves to actually get to the root of it, some questions have multiple assumptions built into them that you have to further question in order to break down all the assumptions, and then you're left at a more fundamental question, for example:

Why do I hate these people? >>> How am I experiencing negative emotions about these people when these people are currently not in my experience? >>> What are thoughts? >> Why are the thoughts about these people affecting me emotionally? How is that even possible? >>> What is the "me" being affected? >> What am I?

Something like that

Just as an example to kind of reiterate what I just said, if you went outside today and saw a cat and a tree, you might say "I saw a cat and a tree", but you have just converted that experience to a communication, which is innacurate.

There is no visual experience of tree AND cat, because you are referring to TWO visual experiences (as you have separated tree and cat). There is one visual experience, which has tree and cat. You separate it and abstract the experience through thought.

It's the entire experience.

You are still trying to point to something in the experience that is you, but you are the experience.

The entire experience cannot point to itself, because the pointer is not the entire experience, it is a subset of the experience, so this "pointing towards what I am" is an inefficient method/medium/tool for identifying yourself.

Because I feel it is relevant, I will share my own synopsis about what Jamie said with the Mario analogy in his "Self-Realization" video:

**Your fundamental identity is what you are experiencing.

So, it's not that you are a human being, but rather, you are what the human being experiences.

Notice that, when you play Mario, even though you are controlling Mario, you are still experiencing the entire game, including Bowser, the goombas, Princess Peach, etc. These are all included inside of the experience of Mario. 

The game isn't JUST a guy named Mario, in the same way that your life isn't JUST a human being. Your life includes other human beings, it involves food, it involves music, etc. So, it's the entire experience of being a human, rather than just this secluded idea of "I am a human."**

And, no word, thought, idea, or communication, will ever capture the experience, because, as stated before, these mediums are a subset of experience, therefore they cannot effectively point to experience.

As Jamie said, there are smarter and more holistic answers, like "I am consciousness" or "I am my entire experience", but these are JUST answers. Answers are not you. You do not exist as an answer. Answers are knowledge. Answers are just a limited sense perception, which is a subset of experience. So, it is still a trap to get stuck to answers. The medium is just wrong.

I'm not saying awareness is identification. I'm saying that this thing that feels the need to identify with something and say "My identity is awareness" is a thought form, and you cannot experience or make contact with awareness through these thought forms or identities.

This is an interesting question actually, not dumb, made me think a bit.

So you've basically noticed that whether you identify with "awareness" or "human body", it seems like thought won't be any of these things, so it seems irrelevant to change or recontextualize your identity.

However, it is actually relevant, because the only reason you're able to "change" identities is because those identities are not you. They're just identities, which are limited subsets of experience. Your thought forms are just changing. "I am a human body" is a thought form. "I am awareness", although it is a smarter and more holistic answer, it is ultimately still just a thought form pointing to something, although if it is actually realized, then there will be no more identities, because identities/thoughts are a subset of awareness, and awareness is what you claim to be. So, identities/thoughts are the wrong medium for accessing the entirety of awareness.

Basically, identifying with being a human body is an unseen thought. Same goes for identifying with awareness. In both cases, a subset of experience is trying to identify with experience, which is impossible. You don't have to put the mental effort of identifying with anything, because you are already you. You can't change it. You're trying to turn awareness into a thought form, which is not possible. Otherwise, what is it that is trying to identify with awareness? Why does awareness need to go through the effort of identifying with itself? It's just another thought, albeit a sneakier and more holistic one.

A flower does not have to identify with anything. The sky does not have to identify with anything. They all just exist as what they are. Just like you.
